The history of the internet begins in the late 1960s with ARPANET, funded by the US Department of Defense. The first message was sent on October 29, 1969, between UCLA and Stanford. The system crashed after transmitting just two letters. Over the following decades, the network grew from a handful of university nodes to the global infrastructure we know today. Tim Berners-Lee invented the World Wide Web in 1989, and by the mid-1990s, commercial internet access had transformed communication, commerce, and culture worldwide.

text: When evaluating a machine learning model, it is important to understand precision and recall. Precision measures how many positive predictions were correct, while recall measures how many actual positives were correctly identified. There is often a tradeoff between these metrics. A spam filter with high precision but low recall would rarely mark good emails as spam, but would miss many spam messages. The F1 score combines both metrics into a single number, calculated as the harmonic mean of precision and recall.

text: Object-oriented programming organizes code into classes and objects that encapsulate data and behavior. The four main principles are encapsulation, inheritance, polymorphism, and abstraction. Encapsulation bundles data and methods within a single unit. Inheritance allows new classes to extend existing ones. Polymorphism enables objects of different classes to be treated through a common interface. Abstraction hides implementation details and exposes only necessary functionality.

text: Climate change is driven by greenhouse gases, primarily carbon dioxide from fossil fuels. The greenhouse effect itself is natural and essential. Without it, Earth would be about 33 degrees Celsius colder. However, human activities have increased CO2 from about 280 parts per million before the Industrial Revolution to over 420 ppm today. This enhanced effect causes rising temperatures, changing weather patterns, and sea level rise.

text: The system of checks and balances in the United States was designed to prevent any single branch from becoming too powerful. The legislative branch makes laws, the executive enforces them, and the judicial interprets them. Each branch can check the others: the President can veto legislation, Congress can override vetoes, and the Supreme Court can declare laws unconstitutional.

text: Understanding economics requires studying multiple perspectives. In academic settings, students learn to question assumptions and think critically. The field has evolved significantly over the past century. New methodologies enable researchers to explore previously impossible questions. Current trends suggest interdisciplinary approaches will become increasingly important. The instructions for learning about this topic involve reading widely, engaging with primary sources, and discussing ideas with peers.
